clean_story:
Unexpected discoveries. Science’s happy accidents.


"Serendipity" comes from an old Persian tale, The Three Princes of Serendip, who kept finding things they weren’t looking for—just like scientists sometimes do.


Science is often seen as careful planning: hypotheses, experiments, results. But some of the biggest breakthroughs came from mistakes, curiosity, or pure luck.


Penicillin, the first antibiotic, was discovered in 1928 when Alexander Fleming noticed mold killing bacteria in a forgotten petri dish. He didn’t throw it away—he studied it. That mold, Penicillium, later saved millions of lives.


Microwaves? A melted candy bar in Percy Spencer’s pocket. He was testing radar equipment in 1945 when he realized the magnetron tube was heating his snack. First microwave oven: 1947.


Viagra started as a heart drug. During trials, patients reported an unexpected side effect—leading to a billion-dollar treatment for erectile dysfunction.


Serendipity isn’t just luck. It’s noticing the odd result, asking why, and following the clue.


Cross-discipline collisions. Failed experiments with hidden value. The art of paying attention.
